abstracts.cdata!:
As part of the Senegal River Basin Water
            and Environmental Management Project, the fourth component -
            micro-grants program - provides opportunities for
            small-scale subproject implementation activities on local,
            and community-based efforts, to be prepared locally in
            compliance with a design criteria that takes into
            consideration environmental, and social impacts. This
            environmental management Framework (EMF) identifies the
            process to implement micro-grant-funded activities, within
            the framework of national environmental policies, and
            provides mechanisms to assess impacts at the national level.
            It is recommended to identify regional priority actions, and
            prepare national micro-grant action plans, where each
            riparian country would prioritize issues, and areas to
            provide a strategic framework for resource allocation, that
            includes spatial, and thematic priorities for
            implementation. Likewise, training assistance, and workshops
            should be developed for the environmental, and social
            design, as well as for the screening process, to be able to
            review, implement, and monitor program objectives; and, an
            information, promotional campaign encouraged, intended to
            engage rural communities in building their own capacity, and
            mechanisms to utilize resources in a sustainable manner.
            Priority issues in the Senegal River Basin include land
            degradation, deforestation, soil erosion, overgrazing, and
            desertification, in addition to adversity on water resources
            management. To this end, soil erosion control measures will
            be established, namely by reforestation practices, improved
            farm management practices, and pastoral land management.
            Furthermore, stream banks will be restored by controlling
            water weeds, and invasive species, and, by improving the
            flow from irrigation ditches, to enhance water quality;
            local wetland habitats will be restored through the
            establishment of community wetland protection and
            surveillance groups, to also protect community nature
            reserves, and implement small-scale research on wildlife and habitats.
